Modeling the Ferroelectric Phase Transition in Perovskite Relaxors and New Corresponding Solving Method Yi-Neng Huang 1,2 * and Li-Li Zhang 1,2 1. Xinjiang Laboratory of Phase Transitions and Microstructures in Condensed Matters, College of Physical Science and Technology, Yili Normal University, China 2. National Laboratory of Solid State Microstructures, school of Physics, Nanjing University, China Abstract Three-dimensional-random-site-Ising-model (3D-RSIM) along with the Glauber dynamics of pseudo-spins (PSs) is applied for the first time to study the relaxion- ferroelectric-phase-transition (RFPT) of perovskite-relaxor-ferroelectrics (PRFEs) in detail. To solve this model, we proposed a new method, mean-field of PS-strings (MF-PSSs), which includes the effect of the interfaces between the groups with or without PSs. We find: 1) 3D-RSIM is a mixed system consisting of permanent-paraelectric-subsystem (PPSS), low-transition-temperature ferroelectric-subsystem (LTT-FSS), and high-transition- temperature ferroelectric-subsystem (HTT-FSS). The contents of these three subsystems change with the PS concentration ( ÔÅ¶ ) of the model; 2) When ÔÅ¶ < ÔÅ¶ p ( ÔÅ¶ p is the percolation threshold of the 3D-RSIM), HTT-FSS dominates the whole system. On cooling, the system undergoes an inhomogeneous-diffuse-ferroelectric-phase-transition (IDFPT), and as ÔÅ¶ increases, it shows a crossover from the critical, gradually to Vogel-Fulcher, and to Arrehnius type slowdown. Specifically, we observe this crossover from the relationship between the peak temperature (T m ) of the real susceptibility of the correlated relaxation of PSs and angular frequency ( ÔÅ∑ ); 3) When ÔÅ¶ = ÔÅ¶ p , the three subsystems have comparable contents. However, when ÔÅ¶ > ÔÅ¶ p , PPSS becomes the dominating subsystem. As temperature decreases, the spontaneous polarization and specific heat of the whole system show an IDFPT, but T m shifts to lower temperature with ÔÅ∑ until 0K. Since the relaxation time of * Email: ynhuang@nju.edu.cn

PPSS rapidly increases at lower temperature and diverges at 0K, during a cooling process at a limited rate, PPSS must be frozen at a certain temperature, i.e. PS glass transition occurs. In short, with the increase of ÔÅ¶ , 3D-RSIGM gradually evolves from the IDFPT system to PS glass system, and ÔÅ¶ p is the characteristic concentration of this evolution. Moreover, based on the coupling between PSs and crystal lattice, we also give a new possible mechanism of Burns transformation. The model predictions in this paper are consistent with the corresponding Monte Carlo simulations and typical PRFE experimental results.

1. Introduction Since the discovery of relaxor-ferroelectrics (RFEs) by Smolenskii and co-workers in 1954 [1-3], RFEs have been often studied by many researchers [4-16] due to their (potential) important applications based on their huge susceptibility, piezoelectric coefficient... [5-7] However, unlike the conventional-ferroelectric-phase-transition (CFPT), the mechanism of relaxion-ferroelectric-phase-transition (RFPT) is not well understood [4-25]. Among the existing RFPT theories, there are some main influencing ones. In 1970, Smolenskii calculated the distribution of microscopic component concentration, proposing a composition disorder model to calculate the static susceptibility of RFEs based on an assumption that the local phase transition temperature is proportional to the microscopic concentration [3]. Random field theory studied by Westphal et al. emphasized the influence of such field to the phase transition and domain structures, but this theory is lack of quantitative predictions to compare with experiments [17-20]. In the early 1990s, Viehland et al. suggested a polar glass model based on the coupling between polar-nanoregions (PNRs), but they did not give a clear model Hamiltonian and its solutions [21-23]. The spherical random-field random-bond theory by Blinc et al. treated PNRs as effective dipoles, assuming they are in a random Gaussian internal field with their interactions also following a Gaussian distribution. This theory successfully predicted the ferroelectric phase transition and effective dipole glass transition with specific parameters. However, it has an unphysical assumption that the effective dipoles have an infinite long and strong interactions [24,25]. To make this theory better, we can further calculate the dynamics especially the complex susceptibility of the system, as well as writing down the distributions of the PNRs, the random field, and random bond on a microscopic level. RFEs is mainly discovered in perovskite-relaxor-ferroelectrics (PRFEs). In section 2, we first apply the three-dimensional-random-site-Ising-model (3D-RSIM) along with the Glauber dynamics of pseudo-spins (PSs), referred as 3D-RSIGM, to study the RFPT in PRFEs in detail. In section 3, a new method of solving 3D-RSIGM is proposed, which is

the mean-field of PS-strings (MF-PSSs) accounting for the effect of the interfaces between the groups with or without PSs. In section 4, we show computer simulations to calculate the distributions of the length of PSSs and their interaction with their nearest neighbors, and then we further calculate the order parameter, specific heat and complex susceptibility of the PSSs and 3D-RSIGM. Moreover, based on the coupling between PSs and crystal lattice, we also give a new possible mechanism of Burns transformation. In section 5, we compare our model predictions to related Monte Carlo simulations and experimental results, and they show good agreements. Later in the same section, we also propose some potential future study of this model to make it better. In the last section, we give the conclusion of this paper. 2. Simplified Model of the RFPT in PRFEs PRFEs are systems in which two or more ions are unevenly distributed on the crystal lattices, also known as compositional disorder systems, for example, Sc 3+ , Ta 5+ in PbSc 1/2 Ta 1/2 O ; Mg 2+ , Nb 5+ in PbMg 1/3 Nb 2/3 O (PM 1/3 N 2/3 ); Zr 4+ , Ti 4+ in BaZr x Ti 1-x O (BZ x T 1-x ) [26-28]. According to the disorder ion valence, it is divided into homovalent (such as BZ x T 1-x ) and heterovalent (such as PM 1/3 N 2/3 and Sr x Ba 1-x Nb O ) PRFEs. Both random-internal- stress-field (RISF) and random-internal-electric-field (RIEF) are generated due to the differences in the size and charge of the disorder ions in the heterovalent PRFEs. However, there is only RISF in the homovalent ones [18]. Taking into account the fact that the heterovalent PRFEs (such as PM 1/3 N 2/3 and Sr x Ba 1- x Nb O ) and the homovalent ones (BZ x T 1-x ) have qualitatively the same characteristics of complex susceptibility [29-39], we could conclude that RIEF has no qualitative influence on the characteristics of RFPT (Of course, there must be some quantitative effects). In other words, RIEF can be ignored in a simplified microscopic model of RFPT. Considering the similarity between RIEF and RISF, RISF can also be neglected in the simplified model.

PRFEs such as BZ x T 1-x [37] and Sr x Ba 1-x Nb O [35] show that with the increase of x, the system evolves from the occurrence of CFPT to RFPT on cooling. Therefore, it is feasible to obtain a reasonable microscopic model of RFPT by appropriately introducing component disorder into the existing models of CFPT. There are two successful schemes to describe CFPT, including pseudo-spin (PS) (Equivalence of the orientation movement of permanent dipoles to spin) [40], and soft- mode [41-44]. Here, we intuitively choose the first one because it would be convenient and direct to introduce the composition disorder. The PS scheme includes three-dimensional Ising-model (3D-IM) and its extended ones. The following takes BZ x T 1-x as an example [45-49] to construct 3D-IM with disorder components, i.e. 3D-random-site-IM (3D-RSIM) [50, 51] of PRFEs. According to the experimental results, the paraelectric-ferroelectric phase transition temperature ( ùëá ùëê1 ) of BaTiO (BT) is approximately 380K, the Curie-Weiss constant of the paraelectric phase ( ùê∂ ùë§ ) ‚âà1.6√ó10 K [37]. There is not any phase transition of BaZrO (BZ) from 2K to 1375K, and the Curie constant of BZ ( ùê∂ ùëê ) ‚âà3.2√ó10 K [47]. According to the Weiss mean field of 3D-IM, the ferroelectric interaction energy ( ùêΩ ) between PSs can be obtained, and ùêΩ(BT)‚âà ùëá ùëê1 = 63K, ùêΩ ( BZ ) ‚âà 0K; the ratio of the permanent electric dipole moments of ÔÅ≠ (BZ) to ÔÅ≠ (BT) is: ÔÅ≠ (BZ) ÔÅ≠ (BT) = ‚àö ùê∂ ùëê ùê∂ ùë§ =0.14 , so as a primary approximation, we can assume ÔÅ≠ (BZ) to be zero in a microscopic model. Therefore, BZ x T 1-x can be simplified as the following 3D-RSIM [50,51]: 1) The crystal lattice structure of the model is simple cubic, and the permanent electric dipoles (permanent dipole moment being ÔÅ≠ ) of concentration (1- ÔÅ¶ ) randomly distribute on the lattice points. The rest of the lattice points are empty. 2) The orientation motion of the permanent electric dipoles is equivalent to two states of PSs. In this paper, ÔÅ≥ ùëñ is used to represent the i th PS in the model, and its two states are represented by ÔÅ≥ ùëñ =¬±1 (ùëñ=1,2‚ãØùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) , where N is the total number of the lattice points with ùëÅ‚Üí‚àû ). The lattice points without permanent dipoles are

equivalent to having no PS. 3) Only the interaction between the nearest-neighbor PSs is not zero, and the interaction energy between the i th and its nearest-neighbor j th PS is ‚àíùêΩ ÔÅ≥ ùëñ ÔÅ≥ ùëó . 4) All PSs in the model are in a heat bath consisting of ions on the crystal lattice at temperature T . Therefore, the Hamiltonian of the model is, ùêª ùëÖùëÜùêºùëÄ =‚àíùêΩ‚àë ÔÅ≥ ùëñ ÔÅ≥ ùëó ùëü ùëñ ÔÅ¶ ùëü ùëó ÔÅ¶ { ùëõùëõ } ùëñ‚â†ùëó (2.1A) where ùëü ùëñ ÔÅ¶ is a random function that ùëü ùëñ ÔÅ¶ =0 for ùëü< ÔÅ¶ , ùëü ùëñ ÔÅ¶ =1 when ùëü‚â• ÔÅ¶ , and ùëü is a randomly generated number between 0 and 1. { ùëõùëõ } represents the summation of all the nearest-neighbors. Moreover, in order to describe the dynamic parameters such as complex susceptibility of the model, we use the Glauber transition probability ( ùë§( ÔÅ≥ ùëñ ) ) [52-54] from ÔÅ≥ ùëñ to ‚àí ÔÅ≥ ùëñ in unit time (appendix 1) is, ùë§( ÔÅ≥ ùëñ )= ÔÅÆ [1‚àí ÔÅ≥ ùëñ tanh( ùêª ùëñ ùëò ùêµ ùëá )] (2.1B) where ùêª ùëñ ‚â°ùêΩ ‚àë ÔÅ≥ ùëó ùëü ùëó ÔÅ¶ {ùëõùëõùëñ} ùëó is the local field of ÔÅ≥ ùëñ , { ùëõùëõùëñ } represents the summation of the nearest-neighbors of ÔÅ≥ ùëñ ; ÔÅÆ = ÔÅÆ exp(‚àí ùëà ùêµ ùëò ùêµ ùëá ) , ùëà ùêµ is the energy barrier that PSs stride over during the transition from ÔÅ≥ ùëñ to ‚àí ÔÅ≥ ùëñ , and ÔÅÆ is the orientation vibration frequency of PSs in their local energy valleys. For convenience, 3D-RSIM with the Glauber transition probability is called as 3D-random-site-Ising-Glauber-model (3D-RSIGM). The reasons for choosing Glauber transition probability are: 1) The Weiss mean-field form of 3D-RSIGM with ÔÅ¶ =0 is same as Mason theory [55] describing the critical relaxation of 2 nd order CFPT [56], which is nearly consistent with experiments; 2) For the correlated relaxation of multi-PSs, the MF-PSSs of 3D-RSIGM when ÔÅ¶ ‚Üí0 gives the similar critical slowdown of relaxation time to the theory (section 4.3 of this article). We can imagine that for BZ x T 1-x , ÔÅ¶ ‚âàx , ùêΩ , ÔÅ≠ , and ùëà ùêµ are almost irrelevant to x

when x is small. However, when x is large enough, ÔÅ¶ >x , ùêΩ , ÔÅ≠ , and ùëà ùêµ will decrease as x increases due to the RISF. In addition, PM 1/3 N 2/3 , PbZn 1/3 Nb 2/3 O and PbMg 1/3 Ta 2/3 O correspond to 3D-RSIGM of ÔÅ¶ ‚âà 1/3. For the more complicated case of Sr x Ba 1-x Nb O , the relationship between ÔÅ¶ and x still needs to be studied. It is worth noting that 3D-RSIM is recognized as one of the realistic models of spin glasses (such as BiSc x Mn 1-x O ) [57-62]. Taking into account the similarity of physical quantities of PRFEs and spin glasses with temperature and frequency, it can be considered that 3D-RSIM is also one of the realistic simplified models of PRFEs. The solution of 3D-RSIGM consists of calculating: 1) the thermodynamic quantities of 3D-RSIM, such as order parameters, static susceptibility, and specific heat; 2) the dynamic parameters of 3D-RSIGM, such as complex susceptibility. 3. New Mean-Field of PS-Strings to Solve 3D-RSIGM According to the author's knowledge, the exact partition function of 3D-RSIM (including 3D-IM) have not yet been obtained. The approximate solving methods are renormalization group theory (RGT) [63,64] etc. Below, we illustrate the difficulties to solve 3D-RSIM from simple examples. It can be imagined that in 3D-RSIM for ùëÅ‚Üí‚àû , the following two subsystems must be included: 1) Finite one-dimensional-Ising-model (1D-IM) [65] of PSs. The exact solution shows that 1D-IM is always at paraelectric state [66-67]. This article refers to this kind of subsystem as the permanent-paraelectric-subsystem (PPSS). 2) Finite two-dimensional-Ising-model (2D-IM) of PSs. Its exact solution indicates that a diffuse peak of specific heat appears at a certain temperature [68, 69], and the total spontaneous polarization is zero [70], which leads to the conclusion that there is not any phase transition in finite 2D-IM. However, according to Imry-Ma theory [71], this originates from the boundary effect of finite systems, which leads to the multi-domain

formation in ferroelectric phase. Now, it is widely believed that there is a diffuse- ferroelectric-phase-transition (DFPT) in finite 2D-IM. Here, this kind of subsystem is called as ferroelectric-subsystem (FSS). 3D-RSIM includes both PPSSs and FSSs, and the phase transition temperature of FSS has a distribution. Therefore, in addition to the physical quantities, such as order parameter, specific heat, and susceptibility of CFPT in homogeneous systems, the description of 3D- RSIM also requires the contents of different subsystems. The coexistence of PPSS and FSS in 3D-RSIM also indicates that RGT [63,64] has the following problems: 1) For ÔÅ¶ < ÔÅ¶ p ( ÔÅ¶ p ‚âà0.69 , the percolation threshold) [72], the model has a 2 nd order CFPT with temperature according to this theory. This obviously ignores PPSS, especially when ÔÅ¶ is close to ÔÅ¶ p ; 2) Based on RGT, the model has no phase transition when ÔÅ¶ ‚â• ÔÅ¶ p , which clearly neglects the phase transition of FSS. The finite series expansion method for solving 3D-IM is only accurate at either low or high temperatures, and the calculation error is larger near the phase transition. The coexistence of PPSS and FSS in 3D-RSIM will further increase the error of this method [73]. In this paper, we propose a new mean-field of multi-PSs, i.e. mean-field of PS-strings (PSSs) to solve 3D-RSIGM, and it is called MF-PSSs to distinguish from the mean-field of straight spin chains for solving 3D-IM [74]. The definition of a PSS is that any internal PS is connected to two nearest neighbor PSs, and the endpoint PS only to one nearest- neighbor PS in the string. Here, a PSS containing ùëõ PSs is expressed as n-PSS. MF-PSSs includes: 1) PSS construction in 3D-RSIM: (1) Connect the nearest-neighbor PSs into short PSSs along the z-axis direction of the crystal lattice; (2) Any two nearest neighbor endpoints of the short PSSs are connected along the y-axis direction (An endpoint already connected to a PSS is no longer reconnected); (3) Continue to connect any two nearest

neighbor endpoints along the x-axis direction to form long PSSs. This construction process is schematically shown in Fig.1. 2) Count the number of n-PSSs with the string length ( ùëõ ) in the model, obtaining the corresponding distribution function ( ùëû ùëõ ). 3) Count the number of n-g-PSSs (n-PSSs with the nearest neighbor number of PSs being ùëî ) in the model, getting the corresponding distribution function ( ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî ). 4) The interaction between n-g-PSSs and their nearest-neighbor PSs is described by the following mean-field of Weiss type [75] (with considering the interfacial effect between the groups with or without PSs [69]), ‚àíùêΩ ùëî ùëõ [(1‚àí ùëõ ) ÔÅ® ùëõ ùëî + ùëõ ] ‚àë ùúé ùëñ ùëõ ùëñ=1 (see Appendix 2 for details), where ùúé ùëñ indicates the i th PS states of n-g-PSSs, and, ÔÅ® ùëõ ùëî ‚â° ùëõ ‚àëùë† ùëõùëñ ùëî ùëõ ùëñ=1 (3.1) which is the order parameter of n-g-PSSs, and ùë† ùëõùëñ ùëî is the expectation value of ùúé ùëñ (Appendix 3-4). Therefore, the Hamiltonian of n-g-PSSs is, ùêª ùëõ ùëî =‚àíùêΩ‚àëùúé ùëñ ùúé ùëñ+1 ùëõ‚àí1 ùëñ=1 ‚àíùêΩ ùëî ùëõ [(1‚àí ùëõ ) ÔÅ® ùëõ ùëî + ùëõ ]‚àëùúé ùëó ùëõ ùëó=1 (3.2A) From ùêª ùëõ ùëî , the Glauber transition probability ùë§(ùúé ùëñ ) [52-54] of n-g-PSSs is obtained (Appendix 1): For ùëõ=1 , ùë§(ùúé )= ÔÅÆ ( 1‚àí ÔÅß ùúé ) ( 3.2B ) For ùëõ=2 , { ùë§(ùúé )= ÔÅÆ [ 1‚àí ÔÅß ùúé + ÔÅ° ( ÔÅß ‚àíùúé ) ùúé ] ùë§(ùúé )= ÔÅÆ [ 1‚àí ÔÅß ùúé + ÔÅ° ( ÔÅß ‚àíùúé ) ùúé ] ( 3.3C ) For ùëõ‚â•3 ,

{ ùë§ ( ùúé ) = ÔÅÆ [ 1‚àí ÔÅß ùúé + ÔÅ° ( ÔÅß ‚àíùúé ) ùúé ] ùë§(ùúé ùëõ )= ÔÅÆ [ 1‚àí ÔÅß ùúé ùëõ + ÔÅ° ( ÔÅß ‚àíùúé ùëõ ) ùúé ùëõ‚àí1 ] ùë§(ùúé ùëò )= ÔÅÆ [ 1‚àí ÔÅß ùúé ùëò +ùõΩ ( ÔÅß ‚àíùúé ùëò )( ùúé ùëò‚àí1 +ùúé ùëò+1 )] ( 3.3D ) where ùëò=2,‚ãØùëõ‚àí1 , ÔÅ° ‚â°tanh ( ÔÅ∂ ) , ÔÅ¢ ‚â° tanh ( ÔÅ∂ ) , ÔÅ∂ ‚â° ÔÅë ùêΩ ùëá , ÔÅë ùêΩ ‚â° ùêΩ ùëò ùêµ , ÔÅß ‚â° tanh ( ÔÅ± ) , ÔÅ± ‚â° ÔÅë ùëõ ùëî ùëá [(1‚àí ùëõ ) ÔÅ® ùëõ ùëî + ùëõ ] , ÔÅë ùëõ ùëî ‚â° ùëî ùëõ ÔÅë ùêΩ , ùëò ùêµ is Boltzmann constant. 4. Order parameter, specific heat, complex susceptibility, Burns transformation of 3D-RSIGM This section mainly includes: 1) The number of n-PSSs in 3D-RSIM was counted by computer simulation, and the results of ùëû ùëõ and ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî were obtained in subsection 4.1; 2) In subsection 4.2, according to Eq.3.2A, we first strictly calculate the order parameter ( ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî ), static susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî ) and specific heat ( ùëê ùëõ ùëî ) of n-g-PSSs, then obtain the order parameter ( ÔÅ® ), spontaneous polarization ( ùëÉ ùë† ), static susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëùùë† ), specific heat ( ùëê ùëùùë† ) of 3D-RSIM by these results, ùëû ùëõ , and ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî , and get the contents of PSS and FSS with ÔÅ¶ in the model; 3) In subsection 4.3, the complex susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó ) of n-g-PSSs was first strictly calculated according to Eq.3.2, then the complex susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó ) of 3D-RSIGM is obtained based on ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó , ùëû ùëõ and ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî ; 4) A new possible mechanism of Burns transformation is given in subsection 4.4. 4.1 Computer Simulations of ùëû ùëõ and ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî in 3D-RSIM In this article, we use the following computer simulations to calculate ùëû ùëõ and ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî . Fig.5 shows that, ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî of ùëõ=ùëõ ùëù changes with ùëî in 3D-RSIM for series of ÔÅ¶ , which indicates that: 1) There is another threshold at ÔÅ¶ ‚âà0.7 , and this value is near to the percolation threshold ( ÔÅ¶ p =0.69 ) of 3D-RSIM [72] (Here, we consider this threshold is

equal to ÔÅ¶ p ). When ÔÅ¶ ‚â• ÔÅ¶ p , ùëî ùëù ùëõ =0 , and the ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî peak becomes narrow with the increase of ÔÅ¶ ; 2) For ÔÅ¶ < ÔÅ¶ p , ùëî ùëù ùëõ decreases, while ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî peak widens as ÔÅ¶ goes up. 4.2 Order Parameters, Static susceptibility and Specific Heat of 3D-RSIM When the n-g-PSSs is in thermal equilibrium, the corresponding equilibrium value ( ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî ) of ÔÅ® ùëõ ùëî is, ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî =[ ùëõùëç ùëõ ùëî ùúïùëç ùëõ ùëî ùúï ÔÅ± ] ÔÅ± = ÔÅ± e =[ ÔÅß + 1‚àí ÔÅß ùëõùëÑ ùëõ ùëî ùúïùëÑ ùëõ ùëî ùúï ÔÅß ] ÔÅß = ÔÅß e (4.2.1) where ùëç ùëõ ùëî is the partition function of n-g-PSSs corresponding to ùêª ùëõ ùëî (Appendix 3), also see Appendix 3 for ùëÑ ùëõ ùëî , ÔÅß e ‚â°tanh ( ÔÅ± e ) , and ÔÅ± e ‚â° ÔÅë ùëõ ùëî ùëá [(1‚àí ùëõ ) ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî + ùëõ ] . intra- and inter-string interactions, respectively. Fig.6 shows the variation of ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî , ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî , and ùëê ùëõ ùëî with T for ùëî ùëõ =3 and series of ùëõ . Combining with Eq.3.2A, 2 nd order CFPT (the peak value of ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî is infinite) can only occur in n-g-PSSs with ùëõ‚Üí‚àû . For finite n , n-g-PSSs undergoes a diffuse-ferroelectric- phase-transition (DFPT) ( ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî (Fig.6b) and ùëê ùëõ ùëî (Fig.6c) is a dispersion peak at a certain temperature), and the phase transition spreads to a wider temperature zone as n decreases. In this article, we define the temperature corresponding to the maximum value of ‚àí ùúï ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî ùúïùëá as the transition temperature ( ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî ) of the DFPT of n-g-PSSs. Fig.7 shows ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî , ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî , and ùëê ùëõ ùëî vs T for ùëõ=10 and series of ùëî , indicating that ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî of DFPT moves to low temperature as ùëî drops off (Fig.7b), as well as ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî and ùëê ùëõ ùëî are not zero at temperature far higher than ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî . ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî ‚â°0 for n-g-PSSs with ùëî=0 (n- 0-PSSs), giving that n-0-PSSs is PPSS; n-g-PSSs of ùëî‚â†0 is FSS. Physically, for finite n and ùëî>0 , the non-zero ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî value at temperature higher than ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî originates from that, the existence of the groups without PS makes the energy difference between the orientational configurations of all PSs becomes larger, leading to the probability of the ferroelectric configurations in 3D-RSIM being higher compared with 3D-IM [69]. For series of ÔÅ¶ , ùëÉ ùë† , ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëùùë† , and ùëê ùëùùë† vs T are shown in Fig.8, and it can be seen that: 1) 3D-RSIM has a transition from ÔÅ® =0 to ÔÅ® ‚â†0 on cooling (Fig.8a), i.e. a ferroelectric phase transition occurs at a certain temperature. 2) As ÔÅ¶ increases, ÔÅ® (ùëá‚Üí0) 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ decreases (Fig.8a), indicating that only part of the PSs in 3D- RSIM undergoes ferroelectric phase transition. In fact, the n-0-PSSs in the model is the only PPSS as mentioned above, and the content ( ùëÖ ùëÉ ) of PPSS in 3D-RSIM is, ùëÖ ùëÉ = ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëõùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ‚àû ùëõ=1 ( 4.2.9 ) And the static susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùë† ) of PPSS is, ÔÅ£ ùë† ‚âàùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõ0 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.10) In 3D-RSIM, the transition from 0 to nonzero on cooling happens within a certain temperature range (Fig.8a), while ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëùùë† and ùëê ùëùùë† appear as diffuse peaks (Fig.8b-c). This is due to the spatial distribution of ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî of n-g-PSSs with different ùëõ and ùëî , so that the transition is an inhomogeneous-DFPT (IDFPT). 3) As T decreases, there is an IDFPT when ÔÅ¶ <0.5 ; two distinct IDFPTs (Fig.8b) near ÔÅ¶ = ÔÅ¶ p , and which are called as low-temperature-IDFPT (LT-IDFPT) and high- temperature-IDFPT (HT-IDFPT), respectively; single IDFPT again for ÔÅ¶ >0.8 .

The order parameter ( ÔÅ® ), spontaneous polarization ( ùëÉ ùë† ), static susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùë† ), and average specific heat per PS ( ùëê ùëùùë† ) of n-1-PSSs are, ÔÅ® ‚â° ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëõùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ÔÅ® ùëõùê∏ ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.10A) ùëÉ ùë† ‚â°ùëÅ ÔÅ≠ÔÅ® (4.2.10B) ÔÅ£ ùë† ‚âàùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõ1 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.11) ùëê ùëùùë† = ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëõùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëê ùëõ ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.12) The order parameter ( ÔÅ® 2+ ), spontaneous polarization ( ùëÉ ùë† 2+ ), static susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùë† 2+ ), and average specific heat per PS ( ùëê ùëùùë† 2+ ) of n-2 + -PSSs are, ÔÅ® 2+ = ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àë‚àëùëõùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî ÔÅ® ùëõùê∏ 4ùëõ ùëî=2 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.13A) ùëÉ ùë† 2+ =ùëÅ ÔÅ≠ÔÅ® 2+ (4.2.13B) ÔÅ£ ùë† 2+ ‚âàùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àë‚àëùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî 4ùëõ ùëî=2 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.14) ùëê ùëùùë† 2+ = ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àë‚àëùëõùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî ùëê ùëõ ùëî 4ùëõ ùëî=2 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.15) When ÔÅ¶ is small, n-2 + -PSSs dominate FSS, so 3D-RSIM has a HT-IDFPT; FSS mainly contains n-1-PSSs for ÔÅ¶ is large enough, which shows single LT-IDFPT; Near ÔÅ¶ = ÔÅ¶ p , the contents of n-1-PSSs and n-2 + -PSSs are almost the same in FSS, and both the HT- and LT- IDFPT appear with T . The contents of n-1-PSSs ( ùëÖ ùêπ ) and n-2 + -PSSs ( ùëÖ ùêπ 2+ ) in 3D-RSIM are,

ùëÖ ùêπ = ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëõùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ‚àû ùëõ=1 ( 4.2.16 ) ùëÖ ùêπ 2+ = ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àë‚àëùëõùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî 4ùëõ ùëî=2 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.2.17) In order to quantitatively describe the HT- and LT-IDFPT of 3D-RSIM, this paper defines: 1) The temperatures corresponding to the maximum values of ‚àí ùëë ÔÅ® ùëëùëá and ‚àí ùëë ÔÅ® 2+ ùëëùëá being the phase transition temperatures of n-1-PSSs ( ùëá ùëÉ ) and n-2 + -PSSs ( ùëá ùëÉ 2+ ); 2) To show the dispersion of the phase transitions, the diffuse temperatures ( ùëá ùëë and ùëá ùëë 2+ ) determined by ùëÉ ùë† (ùëá ùëë ) ùëÉ ùë† (ùëá ùëÉ ) ‚â° ùëí and ùëÉ ùë† 2+ (ùëá ùëë 2+ ) ùëÉ ùë† 2+ (ùëá ùëÉ 2+ ) ‚â° ùëí ; 3) The diffuse factors, ùëë ùëù ‚â° ùëá ùëë ‚àíùëá ùëÉ ùëá ùëÉ and ùëë ùëù 2+ ‚â° ùëá ùëë 2+ ‚àíùëá ùëÉ 2+ ùëá ùëÉ 2+ , respectively. The phase diagram of 3D-RSIM is shown in Fig.10, namely ùëá ùëù , ùëá ùëù 2+ , ùëá ùëë , ùëá ùëë 2+ , ùëë ùëù , ùëë ùëù 2+ , ùëÖ ùëÉ , ùëÖ ùêπ , ùëÖ ùêπ 2+ , and ùëá ùëè (Burns temperature, see subsection 4.4 in detail) vs ÔÅ¶ , which indicate that: 1) As ÔÅ¶ increases, ùëá ùëù 2+ first decreases, but it remains almost unchanged after ÔÅ¶ = ÔÅ¶ p ; ùëá ùëë 2+ first goes up slightly, then drops rapidly, and keeps as a constant after ÔÅ¶ =0.8 ; ùëá ùëë first slowly, then drop rapidly, and increases slightly at the end; ùëë ùëù 2+ shows a diffuse peak near ÔÅ¶ = ÔÅ¶ p ; ùëë ùëù decreases first, and then increases a little. ùëá ùëù 2+ is always higher than ùëá ùëù , and ùëá ùëù is almost irrelevant to ÔÅ¶ . 2) With increasing ÔÅ¶ , ùëÖ ùëÉ and ùëÖ ùêπ 2+ , respectively, increases and decreases monotonically, with the maximum growth or drop rate near ÔÅ¶ =0.8 ; ùëÖ ùêπ shows a diffuse peak with the peak position near ÔÅ¶ =0.75 . In other words, 3D-RSIM has three subsystems: PPSS (n-0-PSSs), low-transition-temperature FSS (LTT-FSS, i.e. n-1-PSSs), and high- transition-temperature FSS (HTT-FSS, i.e. n-2 + -PSSs). The dominant subsystem is HTT-FSS when ÔÅ¶ is small; PPSS, LTT-FSS, and HTT-FSS almost have the same

contents near ÔÅ¶ = ÔÅ¶ p ; PPSS dominates the whole system when ÔÅ¶ is large enough. Along with the IDFPTs, there are at least three different kinds of interfaces in 3D- RSIM: 1) Phase boundaries: the interfaces between adjacent paraelectric and ferroelectric regions; 2) Sub-phase boundaries: the interfaces between adjacent ferroelectric regions of different ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî values; 3) Domain walls: the interfaces in ferroelectric regions with equal ÔÅ® ùëõùëí ùëî values but opposite polarization directions. According to Imry-Ma theory [69], the ferroelectric regions in 3D-RSIM must become multi-domains due to the influence of the groups without PSs within and adjacent to the regions. 4.3 Complex Susceptibility of the Correlated Relaxation of PSs in 3D-RSIGM In the vicinity of the transition or critical temperature of 2 nd order CFPT of typical ferroelectrics (such as TGS), not only there is the correlated relaxation of PSs (CR-PSs) (Referred as critical relaxation, phase transition relaxation [55,56]), but also it includes the relaxation of domain walls and other defects [76, 77]. In this section, the linear complex susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó ) of CR-PSs of n-g-PSSs is strictly calculated first based on Eq.3.2 (Appendix 6-9), and then by using ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó , ùëû ùëõ , and ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî , the linear complex susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó ) of CR-PS in 3D-RSIGM is given according to the extended-Wagner-Approximation (EWA) [78]. The complex susceptibility (including the linear and high order) of n-g-PSSs is related to the change of ùë† ùëõùëò ùëî with time ( ùë° ). Due to the interaction between PSs, the evolutions of ùë† ùëõùëò ùëî and ÔÅ∫ ùëõùëò ùëî ( ùëò= 1, ‚ãØ n) is interrelated (Appendix 6). ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó is directly related to the sufficiently small deviation ( ÔÅ§ ùëõùëò ùëî ) of ùë† ùëõùëò ùëî from its equilibrium value ( ùë† ùëõùëò ùëîùëí =ùë† ùëõùëò ùëî | ÔÅß = ÔÅß e ), i.e. ÔÅ§ ùëõùëò ùëî ‚â°ùë† ùëõùëò ùëî ‚àíùë† ùëõùëò ùëîùëí . With ùë° , ÔÅ§ ùëõùëò ùëî ( ùëò=1,‚ãØùëõ ) obey the following homogeneous linear equations (Appendix 8),

ÔÅÆ ùëë ùëëùë° [ ÔÅ§ ùëõ1 ùëî ‚ãÆ ÔÅ§ ùëõùëõ ùëî ]=‚àí[ ùëÄ 1,1 ‚ãØùëÄ 1,ùëõ ‚ãÆ‚ã±‚ãÆ ùëÄ ùëõ,1 ‚ãØùëÄ ùëõ,ùëõ ][ ÔÅ§ ùëõ1 ùëî ‚ãÆ ÔÅ§ ùëõùëõ ùëî ] (4.3.1) where the square matrix [ ùëÄ ] ùëõ,ùëõ is defined also in Appendix 8. The physical meaning of the solution (Eqs.A8.1B, A8.2I and A8.3H in Appendix 8) of Eq.4.3.1 is that, the coupling relaxation of ÔÅ§ ùëõùëò ùëî ( ùëò=1,‚ãØùëõ ) is equivalent to n mutually independent spatial-relaxation-modes (SRMs), which have different relaxation times ( ÔÅ¥ ùëõùëò ùëî , ùëò=1,‚ãØùëõ ) [79] and spatial distributions ( ùë£ ùëõùëò ùëîùëñ Ôºå ùëò,ùëñ=1,‚ãØùëõ ). From short to long ÔÅ¥ ùëõùëò ùëî ( ùëò=1,‚ãØùëõ ), all the SRMs are referred as 1 st and n th SRM, respectively. Fig.11 and Fig.12 show ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõùëò ùëî ( ùëò=1,‚ãØùëõ ) vs ùëá for series of ùëõ and ùëî . We can see that ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõùëõ ùëî has a diffuse peak near ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî , while ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõùëò ùëî ( ùëò=1,‚ãØùëõ‚àí1 ) has not the abnormal, and except ùëõ=1 , ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõùëõ ùëî increases again with decreasing ùëá , until diverges at ùëá= 0K. In addition, the diffuse peak of ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõùëõ ùëî gradually transits to a ÔÅ¨ -type one as ùëõ goes up (Fig.12a), and approximately ÔÅ¥ ùëõùëõ ùëî ~ ùëá‚àíùëá ùëù ùëõùëî , which is consistent with the critical slowdown result of Mason theory [55]. Fig.12b indicates that, as long as ùëî‚â†0 , ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõùëõ ùëî always have a diffuse peak near ùëá ùëù ùëõùëî , and for all ùëî values, ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõùëõ ùëî has the same divergent behavior at low temperatures. Fig.13 and Fig.14 show ùë£ ùëõùëò ùëîùëñ ( ùëò=1,‚ãØùëõ ) of SRMs vs the PS position ( ùëñ=1,‚ãØùëõ ) in n-g-PSSs when ùëõ=3 and 4. Similarly, this article also introduces the nodes of ùë£ ùëõùëò ùëîùëñ ( ùëò,ùëñ=1,‚ãØùëõ ), where ùë£ ùëõùëò ùëîùëñ is equal to zero, or two neighboring ùë£ ùëõùëò ùëîùëñ intersects at zero. Moreover, the n th , ‚ãØ st SRMs, respectively, have 0, ‚ãØ ùëõ‚àí1 nodes, and the larger the number of nodes, the more uneven the spatial distribution of SRM is; 2) For the n th , n-2 th ‚ãØ SRMs whose node numbers are even,

If the measured external field (electric field, stress, etc.) can be coupled with the SRMs, they can be detected. As shown in Appendix 9, the exact results of the real part ( ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚Ä≤ ) and imaginary part ( ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ) of ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó of n-g-PSSs with angular frequency ( ÔÅ∑ ) is, ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó = ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚Ä≤ ‚àíùëñ ùëê ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ =‚àë ÔÅÑ ùëõùëò ùëî 1+ùëñ ùëê ÔÅ∑ÔÅ¥ ùëõùëò ùëî ùëõ ùëò=1 (4.3.2) where ùëñ ùëê is the imaginary unit, and ÔÅÑ ùëõùëò ùëî is the dielectric relaxation strength of the k th SRM in n-g-PSSs, ÔÅÑ ùëõùëò ùëî ‚â° ùëâ ùëõùëò ùëîùëõ ÔÅ• ùê∏ ‚àëùë£ ùëõùëò ùëîùëñ ùëõ ùëñ=1 (4.3.3) Among them, ùëâ ùëõùëò ùëîùëõ ÔÅ• ùê∏ is the coupling strength of the k th SRM with a sufficiently small external electric field ( ùê∏ ) in dielectric spectroscopy measurements. ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó in 3D-RSIGM has a distribution of both ùëõ and ùëî . However, there is still no rigorous theoretical method to calculate the complex susceptibility of heterogeneous systems on molecular scale. In this paper, EWA is used to calculate the real ( ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤ ) and imaginary part ( ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ) of the complex susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó ) of 3D-RSIGM, that is, ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó = ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤ ‚àíùëñ ùëê ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ‚âàùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àë‚àëùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó 4ùëõ ùëî=0 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.3.5) In Eq.4.3.4 and Eq.4.3.5, if ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî ùëõ is a constant independent of ùëõ and ùëî , that is the Wagner approximation (Corresponding to a parallel capacitor circuit) [78]. This is why we call Eq.4.3.5 as EWA in this paper. For a system in which the relaxation units are randomly distributed in space, the Wagner approximation gives relatively accurate results only when the distribution of relaxation time is narrow. For 3D-RSIGM, since the distribution of ÔÅ¥ ùëõùëõ ùëî and ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî are wide (Fig.11, Fig.12, Fig.6b, and Fig.7b), the calculation of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó by EWA (Eq.4.3.5) has relatively large errors. Express the linear complex susceptibility of PPSS (n-0-PSSs), LTT-FSS (n-1-PSSs), and HTT-PSS (n-2 + -PSSs) in 3D-RSIGM as ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 0‚àó , ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚àó , and ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚àó , the corresponding real and imaginary parts are ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 0‚Ä≤ , ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 0‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ , ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚Ä≤ , ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ , ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚Ä≤ , and ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ respectively, it is obtained by Equation 4.3.5, ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 0‚àó = ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 0‚Ä≤ ‚àíùëñ ùëê ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ‚âàùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ÔÅ£ ùëõ 0‚àó ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.3.6A) ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚àó = ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚Ä≤ ‚àíùëñ ùëê ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ‚âàùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àëùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ÔÅ£ ùëõ 1‚àó ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.3.6B) ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚àó = ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚Ä≤ ‚àíùëñ ùëê ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ ‚âàùëÅ ( 1‚àí ÔÅ¶ ) ‚àë‚àëùëû ùëõ ÔÅ≤ ùëõ ùëî ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó 4ùëõ ùëî=2 ‚àû ùëõ=1 (4.3.6C) Fig.17 shows, when ùëà ùêµ =50ùêΩ , ÔÅ¶ = 0.1 „ÄÅ 0.3 „ÄÅ 0.5 (HTT-FSS is the main in 3D-RSIM

from Fig.10b), the calculated ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤ and ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ vs ùëá and ÔÅ∑ by Eq.4.3.5, which indicates that: 1) Diffuse peaks of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤ and ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ appear near the IDFPT, and the peak temperature ( ùëá ùëö ) of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤ is gradually approaching the peak temperature ( ùëá ùëù ùë† ) of ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëùùë† , but the peak temperature of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ has no such limitation as ÔÅ∑ increases; 2) The low temperature side of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤ peak moves towards the high temperature, while the high temperature side changes little, and the peak height decreases with increasing ÔÅ∑ . Both the high and low temperature sides of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ peak shift to higher temperature, and the peak height has a tendency to goes up first and then drops as ÔÅ∑ increases. Arrehnius plot of ÔÅ∑ vs ùëá ùëö ( ‚àí8 ÔÅÆ ‚àí10 ‚àí3 ÔÅÆ ) is shown in Fig.18, when ùëà ùêµ =50ùêΩ , ÔÅ¶ = 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4, and 0.5, and it can be seen as follows: 1) Near critical slowdown of nd CFPT, i.e. ÔÅ∑ ~ ùëá ùëö ‚àíùëá ùëù ùë† for ÔÅ¶ = 0.1 and 0.2; 2) Vogel-Fulcher type slowdown ( ln ( ÔÅ∑ )~ ùëá ùëö ‚àíùëá ùë£ , ùëá ùë£ is Vogel temperature) [80] for ÔÅ¶ =0.3 and 0.4; 3) Arrehnius type slowdown for ÔÅ¶ =0.5 . Obviously, this is due to the distribution of local phase transitions. Fig.19 shows that, when ùëà ùêµ =20ùêΩ and ÔÅ¶ = 0.8 (PPSS, LTT-FSS, and HTT-PSS contents in 3D-RSIM are nearly same), ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚Ä≤ , ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 0‚Ä≤ , ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚Ä≤ , and ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚Ä≤ vs ùëá and ÔÅ∑ calculated by Eq.4.3.6, which indicates that: 1) Relaxation behaviors of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 1‚Ä≤ and ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 2+‚Ä≤ are similar to the results of Figs.18a, c, and e; 2) Since the peak position of ÔÅ£ ùë† appears at 0K, the ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† 0‚Ä≤ peak will move to low temperature until 0K with decreasing ÔÅ∑ . It is worth noting that, except for ùëõ=1 , since ÔÅÆÔÅ¥ ùëõ 0ùëõ rapidly increases at low temperature and diverges at 0K (Figs.12-13), PPSS is inevitably frozen in a certain temperature zone during a cooling process at a finite rate, and the freezing peak of ÔÅ£ ùë† occurs, so called PS glass transition happens. Considering the rapid increase of ùëÖ ùëÉ near ÔÅ¶ p , ÔÅ¶ p is also defined as the characteristic concentration between IDFPT and PS glass

systems in 3D-RSIGM (Fig.10). In fact, except for ùëõ=1 , the average relaxation time of FSS also rapidly increases at low temperatures and diverges at 0K (Figs.13-14), so PS glass transitions will also occur during a cooling process with a finite rate, but the freeze peaks of ÔÅ£ ùë† and ÔÅ£ ùë† 2+ are much weaker due to the influence of IDFPTs. 4.4 Burns Transformation in PRFEs Currently, the interpretation to the Burns transformation of high temperature thermal strain ( ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá ) and refractive index ( ùëõ ùëòùëô Ôºå ùëò,ùëô=1,2,3 ) in PRFEs is based on the macroscopic quadratic electro-strictive and Kerr (quadradic electro-optic) effects [80-86]. Burns et al. [80] propose that the transformation stems from the appearance of polar nanoregions (PNRs) during cooling. Theoretically, the appearance of ùëÉ ùë† will inevitably lead to the deviations of ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá and ùëõ ùëòùëô from the corresponding high temperature values. However, this does not rule out the possibility that other factors may cause the transformation. In this paper, based on the coupling between PSs and crystal lattice in 3D-RSIM, we give a new possible micro- mechanism of Burns transformation (Appendix 10-11 for details). Considering the local-distortion (LD) of the crystal lattice and the change of local- electronic-clouds (LE) induced by the local interaction (LI) between the nearest-neighbor PSs in 3D-RSIM, which is abbreviated as LI-LD and LI-LE couplings respectively, and under the weak and linear LI-LD and LI-LE coupling approximations, the high temperature ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá and ùëõ ùëòùëô of PRFEs are (Appendix 10-11), ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá ‚àíùë† ùëòùëô (ùëá ùëü )‚âà ÔÅ° ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) ‚àíùëê ùëòùëô ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùêΩ (4.4.1) ùëõ ùëòùëô ‚àíùëõ ùëòùëô ( ùëá ùëü ) ‚âàùëè ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) ‚àíùëë ùëòùëô ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùêΩ (4.4.2) Among them, ùëê ùëòùëô and ùëë ùëòùëô are LI-LD and LI-LE coupling constants; ùë† ùëòùëô is the thermal strain caused by the non-harmonic part of the interaction constructing crystal lattice; ùëõ ùëòùëô

is the refractive index independent of LI-LE; ÔÅ° ùëòùëô and ùëè ùëòùëô are respectively the high- temperature thermal expansion and thermo-optic coefficients caused by the non-harmonic interaction; ùëá ùëü is a reference temperature. When the temperature is higher, ùë¢ ùëùùë† ‚Üí0 , so ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá ‚àíùë† ùëòùëô (ùëá ùëü )‚âà ÔÅ° ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) and ùëõ ùëòùëô ‚àíùëõ ùëòùëô ( ùëá ùëü ) ‚âàùëè ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) . As temperature decreases, |ùë¢ ùëùùë† | increases (Eq.4.2.3, Fig.8c), resulting in the deviation of ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá and ùëõ ùëòùëô from their linear behaviors of high temperature, shown in Fig.20. In addition, the Burns temperature ( ùëá ùëè ) increases as ùëê ùëòùëô and | ùëë ùëòùëô | increases. Therefore, according to the above results, the Burns transformation in PRFEs is a crossover of the nonharmonic interaction to LI-LD and LI-LE couplings. 5. Discussions This section mainly includes the comparison of the model predictions with Monte Carlo simulations and PRFE experiments is given in subsections 5.1 and 5.2 respectively. The potential future study is presented in subsection 5.3. 5.1 Comparison of Model Predictions with Monte Carlo Simulations At present, Monte Carlo simulations in 3D- and 2D-RSIM only give the results of specific heat and spontaneous polarization when ÔÅ¶ < ÔÅ¶ p [50,51]. The main conclusions are as follows: 1) The system has a diffuse ferroelectric/ferromagnetic phase transition; 2) The transition dispersity is enhanced and the transition temperature decreases with the increase of ÔÅ¶ . This is consistent with the MF-PSS predictions (Fig.8a and c). It should be noted that the phase transition temperature given by the MF-PSS is slightly higher than that of the simulations, which is the commonality of the mean field of Weiss type. 5.2 Comparison of Model Results with PRFE Experiments The experimental results of ùëÉ ùë† [86-89] and domain structures [90] in S x B 1-x Nb O ,

PM 1/3 N 2/3 , BZ x T 1-x , etc. show that ùëÉ ùë† ‚â†0 below the RFPT, indicating that RFPT is a ferroelectric phase transition. Also, due to the diffusive peak of ‚àí ùúïùëÉ ùë† ùúïùëá with ùëá , rather than the ÔÅ¨ -type peak of CFPT, RFPT is a diffuse phase transition. The domain structures of PRFEs shows that the microscopic regions of ferroelectric and paraelectric phases coexist, and ùëÉ ùë† is spatially inhomogeneous, so RFPT is also an inhomogeneous phase transition. Therefore, RFPT is an IDFPT, which is consistent with the model results (Fig.8a). It is conceivable that RISF and RIEF will further enhance the dispersity of the IDFPT. Specific heat experiments [91-94] of PbZn 1/3 Nb 2/3 O , Sr x Ba 1-x NbO , PM 1/3 N 2/3 , and PbMg 1/3 Ta 2/3 O show that, the specific heat peak corresponding to RFPT appears in PRFEs, which is also consistent with the model results as shown in Fig.8c. According to Refs. [91, 94], the peak heights in PbZn 1/3 Nb 2/3 O , PM 1/3 N 2/3 , and PbMg 1/3 Ta 2/3 O single crystal samples are approximately 7, 5, and 4 JK mol , respectively; when ÔÅ¶ = , the result of 3D-RSIM given by the MF-PSSs is about 5.6 JK mol (Fig.8c). So, the theoretical and experimental results are also almost equal to each other. For 3D-RSIGM of ÔÅ¶ < ÔÅ¶ p , the phase boundaries, sub-phase boundaries, and domain walls generated during the IDFPT will inevitably contribute significantly to the complex susceptibility below the transition temperature. Here, they are collectively referred as ÔÅ£ ùëè ‚àó . Since the relaxations of the boundaries and domain walls are all derived from the overall movement of large number PSs, the average relaxation time of ÔÅ£ ùëè ‚àó is longer than that of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó . Therefore, the main contributions of the complex susceptibility of 3D-RSIGM of ÔÅ¶ < ÔÅ¶ p are, respectively, ÔÅ£ ùëè ‚àó or ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó when ùëá<ùëá ùëù 2+ or ùëá>ùëá ùëù 2+ . For the typical PRFE PM 1/3 N 2/3 , the specific heat experiments [91,94] show that ùëá ùëù 2+ (PM 1/3 N 2/3 )‚âà 300K, and the frequency when ùëá ùëö ‚âàùëá ùëù 2+ (PM 1/3 N 2/3 ) is about 200 MHz according to the susceptibility data [31]. Therefore, according to the model predictions of this paper, in PM 1/3 N 2/3 , the complex susceptibility for ÔÅ∑ higher than 200 ÔÅ∞

MHz is mainly ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó . The experimental results of PM 1/3 N 2/3 single crystals (Fig.1 of Ref.31]) show that, with increasing ÔÅ∑ , the real part peak of the complex susceptibility moves to high temperature that gives the Vogel-Fulcher relation of ùëá ùëö with ÔÅ∑ , meanwhile its peak height decreases, and the imaginary part peak also shifts to high temperature, but its peak height goes up first and then drops. This is consistent with the behaviors of ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó and the Vogel-Fulcher type slowdown of ùëá ùëö with ÔÅ∑ predicted by the present model (Fig.17b, Fig.17d, and Fig.18). Because the measured data of ùëá ùëö vs ÔÅ∑ by different research groups have significant differences in Sr x Ba 1-x Nb O [35,36], they are not compared with the model predictions here. Since x can be continuously adjusted from 0 to 1, BZ x T 1-x is an ideal system to verify the model of this paper. However, due to the limitation of single crystal growth technology, large-size and high-quality single crystals with x>0.2 cannot be grown, which has affected the measurement of some physical parameters (Especially high frequency complex susceptibility) to some extent [37,45]. In addition, because 3D-RSIGM is used for the first time to study RFPT in detail, the relationship between the key model parameters ( ÔÅ¶ , ùêΩ , ÔÅ≠ , and ùëà ùêµ ) and x is not yet clear, there is a certain difficulty in comparison with the experimental results. However, taking into account the similarity of the real part of low and high frequency complex susceptibility of typical PRFE PM 1/3 N 2/3 [31], the analogy of ùëá ùëö vs x given by the real part of the low frequency complex susceptibility of BZ x T 1-x with the corresponding model result of this paper has a certain degree of rationality. The experimental results of the real part of the low frequency (100Hz-500kHz) complex susceptibility of BZ x T 1-x [37] show that: 1) When x increases from 0.15 to 0.75, ùëá ùëö first decreases linearly with x, and then is almost constant after x ~ 0.5 (Fig.11 of Ref.37) This is very similar to the variation trend of ùëá ùëù 2+ with ÔÅ¶ predicted by the present model, except that ÔÅ¶ p corresponds to x‚âà0.45 . This may be due to the RISF produced by Zr 4+ , which annihilates some of the permanent dipoles; 2) When x increases from 0.35

to 0.75, the change of ùëá ùëö vs ÔÅ∑ varies from the Vogel-Fulcher to Arrehnius type slowdown (Fig.8 of Ref.37). This is also consistent with the results of the model in this paper (Fig.18). The existing experimental results show that there are successively intermediate temperature ( ùëá ‚àó ) [84-85] and ùëá ùëè [80-83] above the RFPT. According to the current view, ùëá ùëè is the temperature at which PNRs is generated on cooling, and ùëá ‚àó is the temperature where PNRs changes from the high temperature dynamic to low temperature static. The model in this paper predicts the existence of ùëá ùëë 2+ and ùëá ùëè (Fig.10a and Fig.20) above ùëá ùëù 2+ of the IDFPT. According to ùëá ùëù 2+ (PM 1/3 N 2/3 )‚âà 300K [91,94], the model predicts ùëá ùëë 2+ (PM 1/3 N 2/3 )‚âà 380K (Fig.10a), which is very close to ùëá ‚àó ‚âà 400K given by the neutron scattering experiment [84,85]. In other words, this article may give a new possible mechanism of ùëá ‚àó . In addition, according to the model results in this paper, at the temperatures of ùëá ùëè ‚âà 620K [5,80-82], ùëá ùëë 2+ +ùëá ùëè ‚âà 500K, and ùëá ùëë 2+ ‚âà 380K in PM 1/3 N 2/3 , ÔÅ® ‚âà 0.04, 0.06, and 0.14, and the ratio of the internal energy ( ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùëì ) contributed by ÔÅ® to ùë¢ ùëùùë† , i.e. ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùëì ùë¢ ùëùùë† ‚âà 7%, 9%, and 18%, respectively. According to Eq.4.4.1 and Eq.4.4.2, the contribution of the spontaneous polarization to the thermal strain and refractive index is secondary between ùëá ùëë 2+ and ùëá ùëè in PM 1/3 N 2/3 , and the main comes from the correlation between PSs. This result also avoids the too large ùëÉ ùë† obtained by the quadradic electrostrictive and Kerr effects (Eqs.A10.3 and A11.3), compared to the data of hysteresis and pyroelectric measurements [5]. In other words, above ùëá ùëë 2+ in PRFEs, PNRs with excessive ùëÉ ùë† may not exist. 5.3 Potential Future Study Closely related to the model of this paper, the potential future studies are: 1) To explore new methods that are more accurate than the EWA to calculate ÔÅ£ ùëùùë† ‚àó of 3D-RSIGM, so that quantitative comparison with the corresponding experiments of PRFEs can be performed;

2) To introduce RISF and RIEF into 3D-RSIGM, and the solution of the corresponding models; 3) The relationship of ÔÅ¶ , ùêΩ , ÔÅ≠ , and ùëà ùêµ with x in variable component PRFEs (such as BZ x T 1-x , and Sr x Ba 1-x Nb O ); 4) To generalize the MF-PSSs for solving isotropic 3D-RSIGM to anisotropic cases, so that the anisotropic PRFEs of single-axis tungsten bronze and layer Aurivillius structures can be described; 5) To generalize the model predictions of this paper to the corresponding ferromagnetic systems, in particular spin- glasses; 6) Strong coupling of PSs with crystal lattice and possible structural phase transitions, etc. 6. Conclusion In this paper, 3D-RSIGM of PSs is applied for the first time to study the RFPT of PRFEs in detail. To solve this model, we proposed a new method, MF-PSSs, which includes the effect of the interfaces between the groups with or without PSs. We find: 1) 3D-RSIM is a mixed system consisting of PPSS, LTT-FSS, and HTT-FSS. The contents of these three subsystems change with ÔÅ¶ . 2) When ÔÅ¶ < ÔÅ¶ p , HTT-FSS is the dominant of the model. On cooling, the model system undergoes an IDFPT, and as ÔÅ¶ increases, the relationship between ùëá ùëö and ÔÅ∑ shows a crossover from the critical, gradually to the Vogel-Fulcher, and to the Arrehnius type slowdown. 3) When ÔÅ¶ = ÔÅ¶ p , the three subsystems have comparable contents. However, when ÔÅ¶ > ÔÅ¶ p , PPSS becomes the dominating subsystem. On cooling, the spontaneous polarization and specific heat of the whole system show an IDFPT, but ùëá ùëö shifts to lower temperature with decreasing ÔÅ∑ until 0K. Since the average relaxation time of PPSS rapidly increases at lower temperature until it diverges at 0K, during a cooling process of a limited rate, PPSS must be frozen at a certain temperature, i.e. PS glass transition occurs. In short, with the increase of ÔÅ¶ , 3D-RSIGM gradually evolves from the IDFPT system to PS glass, and ÔÅ¶ p is the characteristic concentration of this evolution.

Moreover, based on the coupling between PSs and crystal lattice, we also give a new possible mechanism of Burns transformation. 4) The model predictions in this paper is consistent with the corresponding Monte Carlo simulation and typical PRFE experimental results. Appendix 2: Weiss Mean-Field Considering Interface Effect Ferdinand and Fisher first [69] strictly calculated the phase transition specific heat of finite two-dimensional Ising model containing ùëõ√óùëõ spins. By comparing with the infinite system, it was found that the boundary effect of the finite system caused the specific heat peak to disperse, and the peak temperature decreases, as well as the influence factor is approximately proportional to ùëõ . This can be understood as that the system energy and interface energy of two-dimensional Ising model are respectively proportional to ùëõ and ùëõ , so the boundary effect factor is approximately proportional to the ratio of the interface energy to the system energy, i.e. ùëõ . For finite three-dimensional Ising model, it can also be obtained that the factor is approximately proportional to ùëõ . For 3D-RSIM, the interfaces between the groups with or without PSs will inevitably lead to the interface effect. This paper also takes that the interface effect factor is approximately proportional to ùëõ . At present, there are two schemes to introduce the interface effect in the Weiss mean- field: 1) Introduce an internal field unrelated to the order parameter ( ÔÅ® ); 2) Modify the Weiss mean-field proportional to the fractional mean-field ( ÔÅ® ùëì ), where 0<ùëì<1 . This paper chooses the first scheme, and the internal field is taken as ‚àíùêΩ ùëî ùëõ ùëì ùëè ùëõ , where ùëì ùëè is the geometric factor of the interfaces ( ùëì ùëè =1 is used herein). In addition, the interfacial effect corrects the Weiss mean-field to ‚àíùêΩ ùëî ùëõ (1‚àí ùëõ ) ÔÅ® ùëõ ùëî . ÔÅÑ ùëõùëò ùëî ‚â° ùëâ ùëõùëò ùëîùëõ ÔÅ• ùê∏ ‚àëùë£ ùëõùëò ùëîùëñ ùëõ ùëñ=1 (A9.6) By Eqs.A9.5-6, it is obtained that the linear complex susceptibility ( ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó ) of n-g-PSSs, ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚àó = ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚Ä≤ ‚àí ÔÅ£ ùëõ ùëî‚Ä≤‚Ä≤ =‚àë ÔÅÑ ùëõùëò ùëî 1+ùëñ ùëê ÔÅ∑ÔÅ¥ ùëõùëò ùëî ùëõ ùëò=1 (A9.7) Obviously, ÔÅ£ ùë† ùëõùëî =‚àë ÔÅÑ ùëõùëò ùëî ùëõ ùëò=1 (A9.8) Appendix 10: Burns Transformation of High Temperature Thermal Strain in PRFEs At present, the experimental results of the Burns transformation of the high- temperature thermal strain ( ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá , ùëò,ùëô=1,2,3 ) in PRFEs are explained based on the macroscopic quadradic-electrostrictive (QES) effect, that is, the crystal strains ( ùë† ùëòùëô ùëÑùê∏ùëÜ Ôºå ùëò,ùëô= 1,2,3 ) induced by the spontaneous polarization component ( ùëÉ ùë† ùëñ , ùëñ=1,2,3 ) are [5], ùë† ùëòùëô ùëÑùê∏ùëÜ =‚àëùëû ùëòùëô ùëñùëó ùëÉ ùë† ùëñ ùëÉ ùë† ùëó ùëñ,ùëó=1 (A10.1) where ùëû ùëòùëô ùëñùëó is the quadradic electrostrictive coefficient. So, the thermal strains ( ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá ) of PRFEs are, ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá =ùë† ùëòùëô +ùë† ùëòùëô ùëÑùê∏ùëÜ (A10.2) and ùë† ùëòùëô are the thermal strains caused by the non-harmonic portion of the interaction that constructs the crystal lattice. When the temperature is high, ùë† ùëò,ùëô satisfies the linear relationship with ùëá , and we get, ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá ‚àíùë† ùëòùëô (ùëá ùëü )= ÔÅ° ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) +ùë† ùëòùëô ùëÑùê∏ùëÜ (A10.3)

Among them, ùëá ùëü is a reference temperature, ÔÅ° ùëòùëô is the high temperature coefficient of thermal expansion caused by the non-harmonic interaction, and it is nearly independent of ùëá . Based on Eqs.A10.1-3, Cross et al. [5] think that the deviation of ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá from the high- temperature linear behavior in RFFEs is due to the emergence of PNRs first proposed by Burns et al. [80-82], which is much higher than that of RFPT, It is conceivable that the variation in the local-interaction (LI) energy of the nearest neighbor PSs inevitably induces a change in the relative position of the ions in the unit cell, that is, the local distortion (LD) of the crystal lattice, which is called as the LI-LD coupling here. It can also be expected that the LD will inevitably lead to the change of the interaction energy constant ( ùêΩ ) between PSs. In this paper, we refer the LI-LD coupling is respectively the strong or weak coupling depending on that it changes or does not change the crystal lattice symmetry. Under the weak and linear LI-LD coupling approximation, the local distortion ( ùë† ùëò,ùëô ùëñ,ùëó ) caused by the interaction between i th and nearest neighbor j th PS is, ùë† ùëòùëô ùëñùëó =ùëê ùëòùëô ÔÅ≥ ùëñ ÔÅ≥ ùëó ùëü ùëñ ( ÔÅ¶ ) ùëü ùëó ( ÔÅ¶ ) (A10.4) where ùëê ùëòùëô is the coefficient of LI-LD coupling. Then, the strain ( ùë† ùëòùëô ùêøùêº‚àíùêøùê∑ ) of PRFEs caused by the LI-LD coupling is, ùë† ùëòùëô ùêøùê∂‚àíùêøùê∑ ‚âà ùëÅ ‚àëùë† ùëòùëô ùëñùëó { ùëõùëõ } ùëñùëó =‚àíùëê ùëòùëô ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùêΩ (A10.5) Therefore, the high temperature ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá of PRFEs is, ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá ‚àíùë† ùëòùëô (ùëá ùëü )‚âà ÔÅ° ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) ‚àíùëê ùëòùëô ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùêΩ (A10.6) It is worth pointing out that, based on the Weiss mean-field of three-dimensional Ising model, ùë¢ ùëùùë† =‚àí3ùêΩ( ùëÉ ùë† ùëÅ ÔÅ≠ ) , and it can be obtained from Eq.A10.6, ùë† ùëòùëô ùëá ‚àíùë† ùëòùëô (ùëá ùëü )‚âà ÔÅ° ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) +3ùëê ùëòùëô ùêΩ( ùëÉ ùë† ùëÅ ÔÅ≠ ) (A10.7)

Which is in agreement with Eq.A10.3. This seems to suggest that the explanation of the Burns transformation of thermal strain in PRFEs based on the macroscopic quadratic electrostrictive effect may include larger errors. Appendix 11: Burns Transformation of High Temperature Refractive Index in PRFEs Currently, the Burns transformation of the high-temperature refractive index ( ùëõ ùëòùëô , ùëò,ùëô=1,2,3 ) in PRFEs are explained by the macroscopic Kerr (quadradic electrooptic) effect, that is, the refractive indexes ( ùëõ ùëòùëô ùêæùê∏ , ùëò,ùëô=1,2,3 ) induced by ùëÉ ùë† ùëñ ( ùëñ=1,2,3 ) are [80-82], ùëõ ùëòùëô ùêæùê∏ =‚àëùêæ ùëòùëô ùëñùëó ùëÉ ùë† ùëñ ùëÉ ùë† ùëó ùëñ,ùëó=1 (A11.1) where ùêæ ùëòùëô ùëñùëó is the Kerr coefficient. So, ùëõ ùëòùëô ( ùëò,ùëô=1,2,3 ) of PRFEs is, ùëõ ùëòùëô =ùëõ ùëòùëô +ùëõ ùëòùëô ùêæùê∏ (A11.2) and ùëõ ùëòùëô is the refraction index that is not related to the correlation between PSs. At high temperature, ùëõ ùëòùëô meets the linear relationship with temperature and, ùëõ ùëòùëô ‚àíùëõ ùëòùëô ( ùëá ùëü ) =ùëè ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) +ùëõ ùëòùëô ùêæùê∏ (A11.3) Among them, ùëè ùëòùëô is the thermo-optic coefficient that is caused by the non-harmonic interaction. Based on Eqs.A11.1-3, Burns et al. [80-82] considered for the first time that the deviation of ùëõ ùëòùëô to the high temperature linear behavior of PRFEs is caused by the emergence of PNRs on cooling, which is much higher than that of RFPT. It is conceivable that the local distortion of the crystal lattice caused by the LI-LD coupling (Appendix 10) will inevitably lead to the change of the local-electron-clouds (LE) in the lattice, which is abbreviated as LI-LE coupling. The LI-LE coupling will also induce

the change in the local optical frequency permittivity of PRFEs, and thus in the local refractive index. It can also be expected that the interaction energy ( ùêΩ ) between the PSs will be modified by the changes of the local electron clouds. In this paper, it is called the strong or weak LI- LE coupling that change or do not change the symmetry of the crystal lattice, respectively. Under the weak and linear LI-LE coupling approximation, the induced local refractive index ( ùëõ ùëòùëô ùëñùëó ) by the interaction between the i th and the nearest-neighbor j th PS is, ùëõ ùëòùëô ùëñùëó =ùëë ùëòùëô ÔÅ≥ ùëñ ÔÅ≥ ùëó ùëü ùëñ ( ÔÅ¶ ) ùëü ùëó ( ÔÅ¶ ) (A11.4) where ùëë ùëòùëô is the LI-LE coupling coefficient. The refractive index ( ùëõ ùëòùëô ùêøùêº‚àíùêøùê∂ ) of PRFEs due to LI-LE coupling is, ùëõ ùëòùëô ùêøùêº‚àíùêøùê∂ ‚âà ùëÅ ‚àëùëõ ùëòùëô ùëñùëó { ùëõùëõ } ùëñ,ùëó =‚àíùëë ùëòùëô ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùêΩ (A11.5) Therefore, the high temperature ùëõ ùëòùëô is, ùëõ ùëòùëô ‚àíùëõ ùëòùëô ( ùëá ùëü ) ‚âàùëè ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) ‚àíùëë ùëòùëô ùë¢ ùëùùë† ùêΩ (A11.6) According to the internal energy results of Weiss mean-field in three-dimensional Ising model (Appendix 10) and Eq.A11.6, we obtain, ùëõ ùëòùëô ‚àíùëõ ùëòùëô ( ùëá ùëü ) ‚âàùëè ùëòùëô ( ùëá‚àíùëá ùëü ) +3ùëë ùëòùëô ùêΩ( ùëÉ ùë† ùëÅ ÔÅ≠ ) (A11.7) which is consistent with Eq.A11.3. This seems to indicate that, the interpretation of the Burns transition of the refractive index in PRFEs based on the macroscopic Kerr effect may include large errors. References [1] G. A.
